>> Why are you writing multiple tests in a single method? Each test
>should be its own method. You defeat the point of JUnit by using it
>this way.
>>
>
>Well, I use Eclipse with JUB plugin to automatically generate Junit
>test class. For each method being tested, only one corresponding
>method in the test class will be generated. However, for each method
>being tested, there are quite a few test cases. Do I need to create a
>new test method for each test case? Given the above code snippet as
>example, do I need to separate DumpOutputTest into DumpOuputTestOne()
>and DumpOutputTestTwo()?

Please Google "Kent Beck Smalltalk testing" and read the article Kent wrote that introduced the first xUnit platform for Smalltalk. Don't worry too much about the code being in Smalltalk; just read the text.

Each test executes in a separate instance of TestCase. JUnit provides an easy way to automatically create these isolated instances of TestCase if you:

* Write each test in a separate method, and
* Name each test method starting with the characters 'test' (example: testDumpOutput)

If you have multiple cases for a given method, I recommend starting by naming the methods this way:

testMethodName_SpecialCase()

Don't just name them "one", "two", and so on... name the special cases so that the names of the tests make sense to you months from now when you read the code again.

Good luck.
